Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 09:02AM PetVet wrote: I was on a clinical trial with Halaven and Herceptin.  They wanted to see how Halaven worked as a first-line drug.  I started in January 2011 and did 9 1/2 cycles (through July).  This was my first chemo so I don't have anything to compare it to. (Three week cycles - herceptin/halaven on day 1, halaven only on day 8, third week off.) As far as side effects - at first I just had some fatigue and constipation.  I received my Halaven with steroids, an anti-nausea drug and benedryl.  The premeds may have been part of the trial (I'm not sure).  At the beginning, my worst SE's were from the steroids they gave me as the pre-med.  I did lose my hair and ended up getting it shaved off.  (I started chemo on January 12 and lost my hair on January 27.)  It started growing back while I was on Halaven though. By early March, I started noticing that my mouth and tongue felt swollen and sore.  This gradually increased with each treatment.  I never actually had any open sores in my mouth.  Just very sore and a severe metallic taste in my mouth. At the end of treatment, I ended up with some neuropathy (tingling toe, change in balance) so we decided to stop. I've read other people's accounts of Halaven and no one else (that I've read) has had the sore mouth or neuropathy.   As far as results, I can't complain.  I started with lung mets too numerous to count with three nodules large enough to measure.  I had CT scans every 6 weeks at the beginning of the trial and had marked regression in the three nodules after just 6 weeks.  Every CT scan since then has showed stable disease.  They're unsure now if the nodules are cancer being held in check by the herceptin only, scar tissue or necrotic tissue.  They only way they can tell is via  a lung biopsy (not big enough to hit with a needle so a no-go for both me and my oncologist) or monitoring for progression via CT scans. I have my next scan in November so have my fingers crossed. Hope this helps.  Like I said, maybe my SEs weren't typical... Julie

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2007 07:11AM PetVet wrote: I was diagnosed with Paget's disease in May of this year.  I had an itchy, scaly nipple and ended up at a dermatologist.  She took a biopsy and it came back as Paget's.  Have you had a mammogram yet?  Once I had that diagnosis I went for a breast exam that same day and had a diagnostic mammogram the next day where they discovered DCIS. Don't start worrying until you get your biopsy results.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 07:24PM PetVet wrote: I actually had an underlying cancer...  I had widespread DCIS in the breast with Paget's.  I ended up getting a double mastectomy since I had a huge history of breast cancer in my family (prophylactic in the other breast).  I didn't have to have any other treatment (chemo or radiation).  My sentinel node biopsy came back negative.  See...I knew I wouldn't be able to answer your specific questions!  My paget's was actually diagnosed by a dermatologist with quick referral for a mammogram and MRI.  I ended up having some abnormal changes in my prophylactic breast but I'm not sure that was in any way related to the paget's.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2013 04:24PM PetVet wrote: My heart breaks for you. You know you did the right thing with Molly but putting an animal down for aggression or behavior causes a huge amount of stress and guilt on the owner. Let yourself grieve and heal... I didn't realize that you were having problems again with C. diff. That sucks. Are they planning to do more diagnostics to determine possible progression or are your CTC's usually pretty accurate? Don't lose hope until you have solid answers! What is happening to you is totally unfair and you have a right to feel the way you do. Julie

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2015 07:42AM PetVet wrote: KLynn - I just saw your post regarding Cyberknife for lung mets. I didn't specifically have Cyberknife but did have SBRT (stereotactic body radiation) the middle of December. I'm not sure but I think the only difference may be the type of machine they use. (FYI - they used the Novalis with me.) I have two persistent mets in my left lung that aren't responding to Herceptin and Perjeta. In December, they measured approximately 3 cm in diameter and were becoming more active on PET scan. The SBRT required me to have gold markers (they call them fiducials) placed in my left lung via bronchoscopy. They then used these fiducials to precisely focus the radiation so it hit only the tumors while avoiding surrounding tissue. Like I said, I had this in December. I had a total of 5 treatments (2 a week). Painless. I won't have a scan until the end of March so am unable to tell you how well it is working. I definitely have my fingers crossed! Julie

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 01:03PM PetVet wrote: I was diagnosed with Paget's in May of this year.  My understanding is that paget's is an external sign of breast cancer.  In my case, it was DCIS.  With DCIS the cancer cells are confined to the ducts and some of the cancer cells follow the duct to the nipple and almost begin "spilling out" and affecting the outer skin.  In my case, I had extensive DCIS throughout my right breast which required a mastectomy.  (And I decided to have my left breast removed also because of a family history of breast cancer.)  If you're already scheduled for an operation, I'm sure you've already had a diagnostic mammogram and/or ultrasound/MRI to determine how extensive your disease is.  If you are just having your nipple removed it sounds like your cancer is confined to a small area (which is good!).  When discussing paget's with my doctors, they said that just because I had paget's didn't mean that my cancer was more aggressive.   I had my double mastectomy at the end of June with expanders placed.  I'm scheduled for my exchange surgery (to get my permanent implants) on the 18th of this month. If you have to have breast cancer, DCIS is the "best" kind to have because the name itself means the cancer is "in situ" or "in place" and does not extend past the ducts. Julie
